Graphical abstract The metal–organic framework Cr-MIL-101 was found to be active in the solvent-free coupling of CO2 and epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates at both high-pressure (100atm CO2) and low-pressure (8atm CO2) conditions in the temperature range of 25–120°C. Highlights ► Cr-MIL-101 is an effective catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. ► The presence of TBABr co-catalyst is required at room temperature. ► The possibility of the catalyst recovery and recycling was explored. The catalytic performance of the metal–organic framework Cr-MIL-101 in solvent-free coupling of CO2 and epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates has been explored at both high-pressure (100atm CO2) and low-pressure (8atm CO2) conditions in the temperature range of 25–120°C. The presence of tetrabutylammonium bromide as co-catalyst was found to be crucial for the formation of the cyclic carbonates at mild reaction conditions (8atm CO2, 25°C). The yield of the styrene carbonate attained 95% at 98% substrate conversion after 48h. Cycloaddition of CO2 to propylene oxide gave propylene carbonate with 82% yield at 91% conversion after 24h. Heterogeneous nature of catalysis was proved by hot catalyst filtration test, indicating no leaching of active chromium species. However, a deterioration of the catalytic properties occurred after catalyst recycling due to pores blockage with the reaction products and gradual degradation of the MIL-101 structure. Keywords Carbon dioxide Cyclic carbonates Cycloaddition MIL-101 Heterogeneous catalysis Metal–organic framework 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide has received great attention as an abundant, cheap, non-toxic and renewable C1 resource, and the development of the methods for its activation at mild conditions is an attractive research goal [1,2]. The selective cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is a potentially significant approach for both chemical utilization of CO2 and production of the cyclic carbonates, which finds a wide application as a raw material in the synthesis of polycarbonates and glycols as well as electrolyte solvents for lithium batteries, fuel additives, and substitutes for non-environmental organic solvents and toxic chemical reagents [3–5]. A common methodology for the preparation of the cyclic carbonates is based on a coupling reaction of the corresponding epoxides and CO2. Currently, industry uses quaternary ammonium salts, for example, tetraethylammonium bromide, as catalysts for the synthesis of the cyclic carbonates [6]. The recently developed Asahi Kasei process utilizes an anion exchange material with (CH3)4NCl groups as a heterogeneous catalyst for the production of ethylene carbonate, which is used as an intermediate in the synthesis of monoethylene glycol [7]. These processes require high pressure of CO2 (70–100atm) and high reaction temperature (100–200°C). This makes them unfavorable from the points of view of energy consumption and safety. Recent reviews discuss numerous homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts used for the synthesis of the cyclic carbonates [8–10]. Homogeneous catalysts include salen, porphyrin, phthalocyanine and other complexes of the main group and transition metals (Zn, Al, Cr, Co, Cu, Ni, Sn) [11–17], quaternary ammonium salts [18], ionic liquids [19], and polyoxometalates [20]. Some homogeneous complexes are effective at low pressure and temperature [12,13,15–17], but a complicated separation of the catalysts from the reaction product limits their application. Several heterogeneous catalysts have been explored for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides, such as metal oxides [21,22], immobilized complexes or ionic liquids [23–25], titanosilicates [26], and zeolites [27]. There are also few examples of the use of the metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), Zn-MOF-5 [28,29], Zn-ZIF-8 [30], Co-MOF-74 [31], and IRMOF-3 [32] in this reaction. The majority of the catalytic systems reported thus far for CO2 cycloaddition requires high-pressure and/or high-temperature conditions. Therefore, the search for new catalysts and energy efficient processes remains to be a challenge. Chromium terephthalate MIL-101 discovered by Férey and co-workers in 2005 is a mesoporous metal–organic framework which possesses extremely high surface area and pore volume, is resistant to air, water, common solvents, and has a fairly good thermal stability (up to 300°C) [33]. This material has a rigid zeotype crystal structure consisting of quasi-spherical cages of two modes (2.9 and 3.4nm). Cr-MIL-101 was reported to catalyze effectively various types of reactions, including cyanosilylation of benzaldehyde, sulfoxidation of thioethers, and oxidation of hydrocarbons [34–38]. Furthermore, this MOF is able to adsorb large amounts of gases, including CO2 [39,40]. These features prompted us to investigate the catalytic potential of MIL-101 for the synthesis of the cyclic carbonates via cycloaddition of CO2 to the organic epoxides. In the present work, we report the results of the catalytic study of this reaction in the presence of MIL-101 under solvent-free conditions, which are attractive from both economic and environmental viewpoints. Both high-pressure and low-pressure conditions were explored. The optimization of the catalytic system to produce cyclic carbonates with maximal yields was performed. The possibility of the catalyst recovery and recycling was evaluated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts and materials Styrene oxide (SO) (97%), propylene oxide (PO) (99%), cyclohexene oxide (98%), tetrabutyl- and tetrahexylammonium bromides (99%) were purchased from Aldrich, and propylene carbonate (PC) (99.5%) was purchased from Acros. Commercially available carbon dioxide with a purity of 98.8% was used without purification. The metal–organic framework Cr-MIL-101 with the formula Cr3F0.8(NO3)0.2(H2O)2O[(O2C)–C6H4–(CO2)]3·nH2O (n ∼25) was synthesized following a procedure similar to that described by Férey et al. [33]. A mixture of 1.2g (3mmol) of Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, 500mg of terephthalic acid (H2bdc, 3mmol), and 0.6ml of 5M HF (3mmol) in 15ml H2O was heated at 220°C for 8h in a Teflon-lined stainless steel bomb. The resulting green solid was passed through a coarse glass filter to remove the unreacted colorless crystals of H2bdc and then filtered on the dense paper filter. The rude MIL-101 was purified by double treatment with N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 60°C for 3h and then by triple treatment with ethanol at 70°C for 2.5h. Activation of MIL-101 was carried out by drying under vacuum at 150°C for 5h and then at 180°C for 2h. The specific surface area and pore volume of MIL-101 determined by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method were 3270m2 g−1 and 1.47сm3 g−1, respectively. The chromium content was 23wt.%. 2.2 General procedure for coupling reaction of epoxides and CO2 at high pressure A batch reactor was charged with styrene oxide (5mmol) and catalyst (50mg; 0.22mmol Cr) and then pressurized with CO2 up to 100atm. All reactions were carried out at constant temperature of 70°С. The mixer speed was 600rpm in all experiments. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and CO2 was released (∼1.5h) and then ethyl acetate was added into the reactor using a syringe pump. After washing the reactor’s walls, the solution of the reaction mixture was dumped into a vessel and analyzed by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) and gas chromatography (GC, see below details of the product analysis). 2.3 General procedure for coupling reaction of epoxides and CO2 at mild conditions Epoxide (18mmol), Cr-MIL-101 (25–100mg; 0.11–0.45mmol Cr), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBABr) (0.15–0.6mmol) were added into a 100-mL stainless steel autoclave reactor. CO2 was introduced into the autoclave, and the pressure was adjusted to 8atm. The mixture was stirred continuously while the pressure and temperature (25–120°C) were kept constant during the reaction. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled in ice-water or liquid nitrogen (in the case of propylene oxide and cyclohexene oxide) and extra CO2 was vented slowly. The reaction products were identified by GC–MS and 1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR). A sample was taken from the reaction mixture, dissolved in CH2Cl2 and analyzed by GC after addition of internal standard (biphenyl) to determine the conversion of styrene oxide or propylene oxide and the yield of the corresponding carbonates. The conversion of cyclohexene oxide and the yield of cyclohexene carbonate were determined by 1H NMR in CDCl3 solution. Styrene carbonate (SC) was isolated from the reaction mixture by column chromatography on SiO2 using a mixture of hexane and ethyl acetate (v/v 100:1) as eluent. The purity of the carbonate was confirmed by GC–MS and 1H NMR spectroscopy. The isolated yield of SC was ca. 10% lower compared to the yield determined by GC. 2.4 Study on catalyst recycling behavior and stability After catalytic run, the reaction mixture was diluted with CH2Cl2 and the catalyst was separated by filtration and washed with CH2Cl2 and acetone. Then, it was either activated under vacuum (treatment I) or additionally treated with DMF at 60°C for 3h, filtered off, washed, dried in air at room temperature (treatment II), and then reused with fresh Bu4NBr added into the system. The catalyst was characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique, and N2 adsorption measurements before and after several reuse procedures. The nature of catalysis (true heterogeneous versus homogeneous) was studied according to the methodology suggested by Sheldon et al. [41]. The content of chromium in the carbonate product was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). Treatments of MIL-101 with PC were performed under the following reaction conditions: PC 2.5mL (30mmol), MIL-101 75mg, TBABr 0.47mmol (when added), P(CO2) 8atm, 25°C, 48h. Then, the catalyst was characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy, XRD, and N2 adsorption measurements. 2.5 Instrumentation The experiments at high pressure were performed in a high-temperature batch reactor Autoclave Engineers with Hastelloy С-276 alloy as the reactor’s wall material. The autoclave was equipped with mechanical agitator MagneDrive® and two thermocouples. The experiments at low pressure were performed in a stainless steel autoclave reactor. GC analyses were performed using a modernized Tsvet-500 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and DB-5MS capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.25μm). GC–MS analyses of organic products were carried out using a HP 5890/II/5971 system (carrier gas He, 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm capillary column HP-5) or Agilent 6890/MSD 5973 system (carrier gas He, 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm capillary column HP-5). 1H NMR spectra of the reaction products were run on Bruker Avance III 500. An analyzer SORBTOMETER-M was used for measuring nitrogen adsorption characteristics and textural properties (specific surface area and pore volume) within the partial pressure of gas-adsorbate from 0.05 to 0.25 (multi-point BET method). FT-IR spectra were recorded on a SCIMITAR FTS 2000 spectrometer. XRD measurements were performed on an X-ray diffractometer Shimadzu XRD 7000S using cupric radiation (Cu Kα=1.5418Å). The thermogravimetric analysis accompanied with mass spectroscopy (TGA-MS) was carried out under He atmosphere on a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG instrument at a heating rate of 10°C/min up to 200°C. The elemental CHN analysis was carried out on EURO EA 3000. 3 Results and discussion Typically, reaction conditions in the synthesis of organic carbonates employ carbon dioxide pressure of 50–100atm and the reaction temperature in the range of 70–150°C [14,19,20,22,28]. We assessed the catalytic performance of the metal–organic framework Cr-MIL-101 in cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide (the latter was used as model substrate) at both harsh (100atm CO2, 70°C) and mild (8atm, 25°C) reaction conditions. The main results are presented in Table 1 along with the corresponding blank experiments. When the reaction was performed at 70°C and 100atm of CO2 without any catalyst, the conversion of SO achieved 13% after 7h, but SC was not formed (Table 1, entry 1). In the presence of MIL-101, the substrate conversion and SC yield attained 97% and 34%, respectively, after 7h (Table 1, entry 2). The preliminary activation of MIL-101 (see Experimental for details) allowed increasing the carbonate yield up to 56% (Table 1, entry 3). GC–MS technique identified 2-phenylacetaldehyde, 1-phenylethylene glycol, and 2,5-diphenyl-1,4-dioxane as the main reaction by-products. Although the selectivity to the desired product was moderate, these results demonstrated that MIL-101 can act as a catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction. In a blank experiment carried out at mild conditions (8atm, 25°C), the conversion of SO was 9% after 24h but SC was not observed (Table 1, entry 4). In the presence of MIL-101, the substrate conversion increased to 19–23% (Table 1, entry 5) but SC yield remained negligible. The increase in the reaction temperature led to the increase in substrate conversion (95–97%) and SC yield (60–62%) in a reasonable reaction time (Table 1, entries 6 and 7). Since a similar product yield can be attained at 70–80°C at both low pressure (8atm) and high pressure (100atm) (compare entries 3 and 6), we may conclude that high-pressure conditions are not advantageous for the reaction studied. Tetraalkylammonium halides are widely used as catalysts for the production of cyclic carbonates at harsh conditions. Moreover, they are often employed as co-catalysts for the reactions of epoxides with CO2 at mild conditions [6, 42]. Indeed, we found that the addition of TBABr as co-catalyst of MIL-101 is crucial for the selective formation of SC at high substrate conversion (entry 8). After 53h, SC was obtained with the yield of 66% (92% selectivity) at 72% conversion. In contrast to the reaction performed at 100atm, preliminary activation of MIL-101 had no effect on SC yield and selectivity when CO2 pressure was only 8atm. Importantly, TBABr alone and Cr(III) in a homogeneous form (Cr(acac)3 complex) did not catalyze the formation of SC at room temperature (Table 1, entries 9 and 10, respectively). A typical kinetic profile of the reaction of the styrene epoxide with CO2 in the presence of MIL-101/TBABr catalytic system is shown in Fig. 1 . Kinetic curves for SO consumption and SC accumulation revealed no induction period. The selectivity to carbonate increased during the reaction course until it reached a maximum of 90% and then remained constant. The main identified by-product was 1-phenylethylene glycol. Its yield was ca. 1–2% at the beginning of the reaction (26% conversion) and reached 3–5% at 72% conversion. Hence, the incomplete mass balance observed at the initial stage of the reaction cannot be explained by the formation of 1-phenylethylene glycol. We may suppose that the reason for this could be a partial adsorption of the SO substrate onto the MIL-101 matrix at the beginning of the reaction. While at room temperature TBABr does not catalyze the formation of SC and the presence of both MIL-101 and TBABr is needed (Fig. 2 A), the situation becomes different if the reaction temperature is raised. So, at 80°C, the cycloaddition reaction readily occurs in the presence of TBABr as the only catalyst. The addition of MIL-101 allows increasing the reaction rate and completing the process within 5h instead of 10h (Fig. 2B). The effects of the catalyst and co-catalyst (TBABr) amounts and the reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of MIL-101 in the cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide have been studied. The increase in either MIL-101 or TBABr loading led to the growth of the reaction rate but did not affect the selectivity to the target product (Fig. 3 A and B). Earlier, Ju et al. [18] demonstrated that tetraalkylammonium salts with a longer C-chain can improve the catalytic results in the cycloaddition of CO2 to butyl glycidyl ether. Meanwhile, we found that the use of tetrahexylammonium bromide (THABr) led to decrease in SO conversion (61% versus 72%) and SC yield (53% versus 63% in the presence of TBABr). The selectivity and the yield of SC went through a maximum (96–98% and 92–95%, respectively) in the temperature range of 50–80°C (Fig. 4 ). When the reaction temperature reached 120°C, the cyclic carbonate yield was only 50% at complete SO conversion. Most likely, the observed decrease in SC yield at high temperature was due to the formation of polymeric by-products. To estimate the scope of the MIL-101/TBABr catalytic system, we studied cycloaddition of CO2 to the other representative epoxides under the reaction conditions that had been established as optimal for the formation of the styrene carbonate in terms of the reaction conversion and the product yield. The results are summarized in Table 2 . One can see that MIL-101 catalyzes effectively the coupling reaction between CO2 and PO to give propylene carbonate with the yield of 82% at 91% conversion (Table 2). The solvent-free conditions allowed achieving high volume yields of SC and PC (1.2–1.4kg of product per liter of the reaction mixture). With cyclohexene oxide, only 27% conversion and 5% yield of cyclic carbonate were observed after 64h (Table 2). The reactivity trend established in this work (propylene oxide>styrene oxide>cyclohexene oxide) is in agreement with the literature data [12–14,16,19,23,24]. We compared the catalytic performance of the MIL-101/TBABr system with other heterogeneous catalysts, including few MOF-based ones, which had been reported in the literature (all these catalysts operate at relatively mild conditions, that is, in the temperature range 25–140°C and CO2 pressure 1–20atm). The data collected in Table 3 shows that the MIL-101/TBABr system allows obtaining SC with the molar and volume yields comparable or even superior to the best yields achieved so far. The mechanism of the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides in the presence of the transition metal catalysts and quaternary ammonium salts as co-catalysts has been addressed in the literature [8,9,12,13,17,25,29]. It was suggested that epoxide first coordinates on a metal center followed by epoxide ring opening under the action of TBABr. Then, the oxygen anion of the open ring (nucleophilic) interacts with CO2 (electrophilic) to form the carbonate anion which converts into the final cyclic carbonate. The observed synergy of MIL-101 and TBABr in the reaction studied allowed us to envisage a similar mechanism (Scheme 1 ); however, further study is needed to verify this assumption. In order to check a possible contribution of a homogeneous catalytic reaction due to active chromium species leached into solution and coupled with TBABr, we performed hot catalyst filtration test (Fig. 5 ). No further substrate conversion in the filtrate occurred after catalyst removal at the reaction temperature, indicating that catalysis is not due to soluble species that might leach from the MIL-101 matrix. Recycling behavior of MIL-101 in CO2 coupling with SO and PO was studied in a few consecutive runs. As one can judge from Table 4 , both SO conversion and SC yield decreased gradually although the catalyst was activated in vacuum before reuse (see Experimental for details). A similar picture was observed with PO as substrate. The N2 adsorption measurements revealed that the BET surface area of MIL-101 decreased from 3270 to 2310 after the first use and to 860m2 g−1 after the second use of the catalyst. The same tendency was observed for the pore volume, which reduced from 1.47 to 1.04 after the first use and to 0.35cm3 g−1 after the second use. These results may suggest that either pore blockage by the reaction products takes place or catalyst loses its structure, resulting in the gradual deterioration of the catalytic properties. Additional treatment of MIL-101 with hot DMF before reuse led to partial improvement of the recycling behavior but did not solve completely the catalyst deactivation problem (Table 4). To understand the reasons for this, we studied the reused catalyst by elemental analysis, TGA-MS, FT-IR, and XRD techniques. Indeed, comparison of the elemental analysis data for MIL-101 before and after the reaction showed an increase in the carbon content of ca. 30%, indicating the appearance of carbonaceous species in the pores. However, TGA-MS of the reused sample revealed no desorption of organic compounds. Hence, we may suppose irreversible sorption of organic products (by-products) on MIL-101, leading to catalyst poisoning. Although FT-IR spectra showed the retention of the principle characteristic bands of MIL-101 after two reuses (Fig. 6 ), the catalyst revealed no X-ray powder diffraction after the second reuse (Fig. 7 , compare spectra A, B, and C). These results, most likely, indicate that the short-range order of the chromium terephthalate has been maintained while the supramolecular zeotype structure had been lost [43]. Interestingly, if the reused catalyst was subjected to treatment by hot DMF and then by hot EtOH (a procedure similar to that used for MIL-101 purification that was described in the Experimental), a limited dissolution of the material occurred, corroborating a partial damage of the MIL-101 structure. Elemental analysis confirmed the presence of 30–50ppm of Cr in the filtrate after separation of the MIL-101 catalyst. However, the hot filtration test (Fig. 5) proved that the soluble chromium species are not responsible for the observed catalysis. Miralda et al. [30] observed similar trends, that is, decrease in both BET surface area and catalytic activity as well as loss of the structural features upon reuse of zeolitic imidazole framework ZIF-8 in cycloaddition of CO2 to epichlorohydrin. The authors suggested that a synergistic effect of the high pressure of CO2 and the high temperature along with poisoning/blocking of the active sites by carbonaceous products could be the reasons for the observed catalyst deactivation and crystalline instability of ZIF-8. However, Cr-MIL-101 is resistant toward extremely high pressure of gases [44] and, specifically, can withstand, at least, 20atm of CO2 [40]. On the other hand, XRD data confirmed the retention of MIL-101 structure after the treatment with propylene carbonate product under the typical reaction conditions, both in the presence and in the absence of TBABr (Fig. 7, spectra D and E). Hence, we may suppose that neither high pressure of CO2 nor carbonate product cause damage of the MIL-101 framework. At the moment, the mechanism of MIL-101 destruction during the coupling reaction is not completely clear. Most likely, a combined action of all the reactants is responsible for this phenomenon. 4 Conclusions The chromium terephthalate MIL-101 catalyzes the coupling reaction of the styrene oxide with CO2 under solvent-free conditions at 8–100atm of CO2 and 70–80°C to produce cyclic carbonates with moderate yields. More importantly, the reaction proceeds effectively at milder conditions (8atm, 25°C) if TBABr is added as co-catalyst to MIL-101. At room temperature, TBABr alone is not able to catalyze the formation of the cyclic carbonate from epoxide and CO2. In the catalytic system MIL-101/TBABr, the reaction rate increases with the increasing amounts of both catalyst and co-catalyst as well as with rising the reaction temperature, keeping the high level of selectivity (90–95%). Under optimal reaction conditions, propylene and styrene carbonates can be obtained with the yields of 82% and 95%, respectively. Solvent-free conditions make it possible to achieve high volume yields of the cyclic carbonates (1.2–1.4kgL−1). Hot catalyst filtration test proved that MIL-101 operates as a true heterogeneous catalyst. However, the catalytic activity tends to decrease after several reuses because of the loss of the MIL-101 regular porous structure, pore blockage, and poisoning of active sites with the reaction products. Partial regeneration of the catalyst is possible by treatment with hot DMF before use in the next catalytic run. Acknowledgments We thank Dr. A.V. Golovin for 1H NMR measurements, Mr. V.A. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic performance of the metal–organic framework Cr-MIL-101 in solvent-free coupling of CO2 and epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates has been explored at both high-pressure (100atm CO2) and low-pressure (8atm CO2) conditions in the temperature range of 25–120°C. The presence of tetrabutylammonium bromide as co-catalyst was found to be crucial for the formation of the cyclic carbonates at mild reaction conditions (8atm CO2, 25°C). The yield of the styrene carbonate attained 95% at 98% substrate conversion after 48h. Cycloaddition of CO2 to propylene oxide gave propylene carbonate with 82% yield at 91% conversion after 24h. Heterogeneous nature of catalysis was proved by hot catalyst filtration test, indicating no leaching of active chromium species. However, a deterioration of the catalytic properties occurred after catalyst recycling due to pores blockage with the reaction products and gradual degradation of the MIL-101 structure.
coredata.dc:title: Cyclic carbonates synthesis from epoxides and CO2 over metal–organic framework Cr-MIL-101
